title: ST558HW2_BaseRprogramming
text:
Create vectors for pre- and post-treatment blood pressure measurements:

pre_bp <- c(120, 151, 125, 126, 115, 132, 132, 129, 134, 139, 127, 122, 127, 135, 133, 128, 147, 138, 140, 132)
post_bp <- c(127, 145, 135, 122, 115, 122, 123, 126, 126, 129, 132, 146, 120, 114, 121, 120, 128, 120, 133, 115)

Generate generic patient names

patient <-paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")
print(patient)

 [1] "Subject_1"  "Subject_2"  "Subject_3"  "Subject_4"  "Subject_5" 
 [6] "Subject_6"  "Subject_7"  "Subject_8"  "Subject_9"  "Subject_10"
[11] "Subject_11" "Subject_12" "Subject_13" "Subject_14" "Subject_15"
[16] "Subject_16" "Subject_17" "Subject_18" "Subject_19" "Subject_20"


Assign names to both vectors

names(pre_bp) <- patient
names(post_bp)<- patient
print(pre_bp)

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       120        151        125        126        115        132        132 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       129        134        139        127        122        127        135 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       133        128        147        138        140        132 

print(post_bp)

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       127        145        135        122        115        122        123 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       126        126        129        132        146        120        114 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       121        120        128        120        133        115 


Calculate change in blood pressure by subtracting post-treatment from pre-treatment measurement, then calculate the average DECREASE (or change) in blood pressure across all patients.

diff_bp <- pre_bp - post_bp
print(mean(diff_bp))

[1] 5.65


Identify patients (by generic name and index) who experienced a decrease in blood pressure after treatment.

#decrBP <- which(BPchange > 0)
#print(decrBP)
print(which(diff_bp > 0))

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         2          4          6          7          8          9         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
        13         14         15         16         17         18         19 
Subject_20 
        20 


Subset the vector of differences to only return those that have a positive change.

decr_bp <- diff_bp[diff_bp > 0]
print(decr_bp)

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         6          4         10          9          3          8         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
         7         21         12          8         19         18          7 
Subject_20 
        17 


Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure for those whose blood pressure decreased.

print(mean(decr_bp))

[1] 10.6

title: ST558HW2_BaseRprogramming
text:
Create vectors for pre- and post-treatment blood pressure measurements:

pre_bp <- c(120, 151, 125, 126, 115, 132, 132, 129, 134, 139, 127, 122, 127, 135, 133, 128, 147, 138, 140, 132)
post_bp <- c(127, 145, 135, 122, 115, 122, 123, 126, 126, 129, 132, 146, 120, 114, 121, 120, 128, 120, 133, 115)

Generate generic patient names

patient <-paste("Subject", 1:20, sep = "_")
print(patient)

 [1] "Subject_1"  "Subject_2"  "Subject_3"  "Subject_4"  "Subject_5" 
 [6] "Subject_6"  "Subject_7"  "Subject_8"  "Subject_9"  "Subject_10"
[11] "Subject_11" "Subject_12" "Subject_13" "Subject_14" "Subject_15"
[16] "Subject_16" "Subject_17" "Subject_18" "Subject_19" "Subject_20"


Assign names to both vectors

names(pre_bp) <- patient
names(post_bp)<- patient
print(pre_bp)

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       120        151        125        126        115        132        132 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       129        134        139        127        122        127        135 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       133        128        147        138        140        132 

print(post_bp)

 Subject_1  Subject_2  Subject_3  Subject_4  Subject_5  Subject_6  Subject_7 
       127        145        135        122        115        122        123 
 Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 Subject_11 Subject_12 Subject_13 Subject_14 
       126        126        129        132        146        120        114 
Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 Subject_20 
       121        120        128        120        133        115 


Calculate change in blood pressure by subtracting post-treatment from pre-treatment measurement, then calculate the average DECREASE (or change) in blood pressure across all patients.

diff_bp <- pre_bp - post_bp
print(mean(diff_bp))

[1] 5.65


Identify patients (by generic name and index) who experienced a decrease in blood pressure after treatment.

#decrBP <- which(BPchange > 0)
#print(decrBP)
print(which(diff_bp > 0))

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         2          4          6          7          8          9         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
        13         14         15         16         17         18         19 
Subject_20 
        20 


Subset the vector of differences to only return those that have a positive change.

decr_bp <- diff_bp[diff_bp > 0]
print(decr_bp)

 Subject_2  Subject_4  Subject_6  Subject_7  Subject_8  Subject_9 Subject_10 
         6          4         10          9          3          8         10 
Subject_13 Subject_14 Subject_15 Subject_16 Subject_17 Subject_18 Subject_19 
         7         21         12          8         19         18          7 
Subject_20 
        17 


Calculate the average decrease in blood pressure for those whose blood pressure decreased.

print(mean(decr_bp))

[1] 10.6

title: ST558HW2_BaseRprogramming
text:
Task 2: Data Frames
Create a data frame object with four columns corresponding to your data above: patient, pre_bp, post_bp, and diff_bp.

treatment_df <- data.frame(patient, pre_bp, post_bp, diff_bp, row.names = NULL)

treatment_df

      patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp
1   Subject_1    120     127      -7
2   Subject_2    151     145       6
3   Subject_3    125     135     -10
4   Subject_4    126     122       4
5   Subject_5    115     115       0
6   Subject_6    132     122      10
7   Subject_7    132     123       9
8   Subject_8    129     126       3
9   Subject_9    134     126       8
10 Subject_10    139     129      10
11 Subject_11    127     132      -5
12 Subject_12    122     146     -24
13 Subject_13    127     120       7
14 Subject_14    135     114      21
15 Subject_15    133     121      12
16 Subject_16    128     120       8
17 Subject_17    147     128      19
18 Subject_18    138     120      18
19 Subject_19    140     133       7
20 Subject_20    132     115      17


Return only rows of the data frame where the diff_bp column is negative.

#df[df$x > 1, ]
treatment_df[treatment_df$diff_bp < 0,]

      patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp
1   Subject_1    120     127      -7
3   Subject_3    125     135     -10
11 Subject_11    127     132      -5
12 Subject_12    122     146     -24


Add a new column to the data frame corresponding to TRUE if the post_bp is less than 120 and FALSE if it is not.

treatment_df$PostLess120 <- treatment_df$post_bp < 120
treatment_df

      patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp PostLess120
1   Subject_1    120     127      -7       FALSE
2   Subject_2    151     145       6       FALSE
3   Subject_3    125     135     -10       FALSE
4   Subject_4    126     122       4       FALSE
5   Subject_5    115     115       0        TRUE
6   Subject_6    132     122      10       FALSE
7   Subject_7    132     123       9       FALSE
8   Subject_8    129     126       3       FALSE
9   Subject_9    134     126       8       FALSE
10 Subject_10    139     129      10       FALSE
11 Subject_11    127     132      -5       FALSE
12 Subject_12    122     146     -24       FALSE
13 Subject_13    127     120       7       FALSE
14 Subject_14    135     114      21        TRUE
15 Subject_15    133     121      12       FALSE
16 Subject_16    128     120       8       FALSE
17 Subject_17    147     128      19       FALSE
18 Subject_18    138     120      18       FALSE
19 Subject_19    140     133       7       FALSE
20 Subject_20    132     115      17        TRUE


Finally, print the data frame out nicely.

knitr::kable(treatment_df)

pre_bp
post_bp

title: ST558HW2_BaseRprogramming
text:
Task 3: List Practice

placebo_pre_bp <- c(138, 135, 147, 117, 152, 134, 114, 121, 131, 130)
placebo_post_bp <- c(105, 136, 123, 130, 134, 143, 135, 139, 120, 124)
placebo_diff <- placebo_pre_bp - placebo_post_bp
patient <-paste("Subject", 1:10, sep = "_")

placebo_df <- data.frame(patient, placebo_pre_bp, placebo_post_bp, placebo_diff)

placebo_df$placebo_PostLess120 <-placebo_df$placebo_post_bp < 120

placebo_df

      patient placebo_pre_bp placebo_post_bp placebo_diff placebo_PostLess120
1   Subject_1            138             105           33                TRUE
2   Subject_2            135             136           -1               FALSE
3   Subject_3            147             123           24               FALSE
4   Subject_4            117             130          -13               FALSE
5   Subject_5            152             134           18               FALSE
6   Subject_6            134             143           -9               FALSE
7   Subject_7            114             135          -21               FALSE
8   Subject_8            121             139          -18               FALSE
9   Subject_9            131             120           11               FALSE
10 Subject_10            130             124            6               FALSE


Create and store a list with two elements: element 1 = treatment, and element 2 = placebo, then name the elements of the list.

my_list <- list(treatment_df, placebo_df)
my_list <- list(treatment = treatment_df, placebo = placebo_df)

Access the first list element using three different types of syntax (the result can be a list or just the data frame).

my_list[1]

$treatment
      patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp PostLess120
1   Subject_1    120     127      -7       FALSE
2   Subject_2    151     145       6       FALSE
3   Subject_3    125     135     -10       FALSE
4   Subject_4    126     122       4       FALSE
5   Subject_5    115     115       0        TRUE
6   Subject_6    132     122      10       FALSE
7   Subject_7    132     123       9       FALSE
8   Subject_8    129     126       3       FALSE
9   Subject_9    134     126       8       FALSE
10 Subject_10    139     129      10       FALSE
11 Subject_11    127     132      -5       FALSE
12 Subject_12    122     146     -24       FALSE
13 Subject_13    127     120       7       FALSE
14 Subject_14    135     114      21        TRUE
15 Subject_15    133     121      12       FALSE
16 Subject_16    128     120       8       FALSE
17 Subject_17    147     128      19       FALSE
18 Subject_18    138     120      18       FALSE
19 Subject_19    140     133       7       FALSE
20 Subject_20    132     115      17        TRUE

str(my_list[1])

List of 1
 $ treatment:'data.frame':  20 obs. of  5 variables:
  ..$ patient    : chr [1:20] "Subject_1" "Subject_2" "Subject_3" "Subject_4" ...
  ..$ pre_bp     : num [1:20] 120 151 125 126 115 132 132 129 134 139 ...
  ..$ post_bp    : num [1:20] 127 145 135 122 115 122 123 126 126 129 ...
  ..$ diff_bp    : num [1:20] -7 6 -10 4 0 10 9 3 8 10 ...
  ..$ PostLess120: logi [1:20] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE TRUE FALSE ...

my_list$treatment

      patient pre_bp post_bp diff_bp PostLess120
1   Subject_1    120     127      -7       FALSE
2   Subject_2    151     145       6       FALSE
3   Subject_3    125     135     -10       FALSE
4   Subject_4    126     122       4       FALSE
5   Subject_5    115     115       0        TRUE
6   Subject_6    132     122      10       FALSE
7   Subject_7    132     123       9       FALSE
8   Subject_8    129     126       3       FALSE
9   Subject_9    134     126       8       FALSE
10 Subject_10    139     129      10       FALSE
11 Subject_11    127     132      -5       FALSE
12 Subject_12    122     146     -24       FALSE
13 Subject_13    127     120       7       FALSE
14 Subject_14    135     114      21        TRUE
15 Subject_15    133     121      12       FALSE
16 Subject_16    128     120       8       FALSE
17 Subject_17    147     128      19       FALSE
18 Subject_18    138     120      18       FALSE
19 Subject_19    140     133       7       FALSE
20 Subject_20    132     115      17        TRUE


Use your list from question 2. In one line of code, access the pre_bp column of the placebo data frame.

my_list[[2]][2]

   placebo_pre_bp
1             138
2             135
3             147
4             117
5             152
6             134
7             114
8             121
9             131
10            130
